edge_1: Slave trader Theophilus Freeman gave Solomon Northup the identity of 'Platt', a runaway slave from Georgia, to hide his true identity.
edge_2: Solomon Northup was sold to plantation owner Edwin Epps, who was abusive and sadistic towards him.

edge_1: Slave trader Theophilus Freeman sold Solomon Northup to plantation owner William Ford after drugging him and delivering him to James H. Birch, the owner of a slave pen.
edge_2: Solomon Northup was sold to plantation owner Edwin Epps, who was abusive and sadistic towards him.

edge_1: Plantation owner William Ford took a liking to Solomon Northup and gave him a violin, but eventually sold him to plantation owner Edwin Epps.
edge_2: Solomon Northup was sold to plantation owner Edwin Epps, who was abusive and sadistic towards him.

edge_1: Tensions between Solomon Northup and plantation carpenter John Tibeats broke when Northup defended himself from Tibeats's violent beatings.
edge_2: Solomon Northup was sold to plantation owner Edwin Epps, who was abusive and sadistic towards him.

edge_1: Epps, unlike Ford, is abusive and sadistic to his slaves. Northup meets Patsey, a favored slave and Epps' top cotton picker.
edge_2: Northup attempts to explain his situation, but Ford sells him to plantation owner Edwin Epps.

edge_1: Epps, unlike Ford, is abusive and sadistic to his slaves. Northup meets Patsey, a favored slave and Epps' top cotton picker.
edge_2: Epps questions and threatens Northup, but Northup convinces him that Armsby is lying. Northup burns the letter.

edge_1: Epps, unlike Ford, is abusive and sadistic to his slaves. Northup meets Patsey, a favored slave and Epps' top cotton picker.
edge_2: Northup destroys his violin after Epps orders him to whip Patsey, which he reluctantly does, but Epps demands he strike her harder, eventually taking the whip and beating Patsey nearly to death.
